questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in the area of his jaw. CBC reveals anemia and lymphocytosis. Biopsy findings from the swelling are seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and biopsy findings point to a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma.

The biopsy image shows tumor cells with multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm, and high mitotic index closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (the "sky"). These cells have a high turnover rate. The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris, they are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris ( the "stars"). This produces a starry sky appearance, which is classical to Burkitt lymphoma. 

Burkitt lymphoma:

  • Most common NHL in children <15 years
  • Associated with translocation of MYC gene of chromosome 8 (Option A)
  • Translocations: t (8;14), t (2;8), t (8,22)
  • Three distinct clinical forms:
    • Endemic: affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla and is EBV-associated (Option B)
    • Sporadic: in adults in western countries 
    • Immunodeficiency associated: HIV infection
  • It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumor, Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% staining with Ki-67)

Histology: Starry sky pattern

Immunophenotype: 

  • The tumor cells express
    • Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda)
    • B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a
    • Germinal center-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6
    • HLA-DR and CD43.
  • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status of the tumors.
    • Endemic BL are EBV positive, express CD21
    • Non-endemic BL in non-immunosuppressed patients are EBV negative and lack CD21 expression

Treatment: Begins within 48h of diagnosis in both children and adults with the use of an intensive combination of chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide and CNS prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with backache. Urine examination revealed nephrotic range proteinuria with Bence-Jones proteins. Laboratory reports showed hypercalcemia.  A renal biopsy specimen stained by congo red seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. Which of the major fibril protein is accumulated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from multiple myeloma. The major fibril protein accumulated in this patient is AL (amyloid light chain) protein.

The above clinical scenario of backache, proteinuria with Bence-Jones protein, hypercalcemia are suggestive of multiple myeloma. The image showing a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized microscopy is indicative of amyloid accumulation in the organ. In multiple myeloma, the amyloid is made from the light chain of immunoglobulins (chiefly λ type). 

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. The abnormal fibrils are obtained by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind to proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid is an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Microscopy :

All types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils and are demonstrated on electron microscopy. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. The stain used for amyloid deposits is congo red staining. It imparts pink to red color to the amyloid under ordinary light. Under polarised microscopy, congo red-stained amyloid shows apple-green birefringence.

Other options:

Option A-  Amyloid β2 microglobulin(Aβ2M) fibrillar protein is seen in hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis in chronic renal failure.

Option B- Amyloid-associated (AA) fibrillar protein is seen in secondary systemic amyloidosis and familial Mediterranean fever.

Option D- Amyloid transthyretin (ATTR) fibrillar protein is seen in the mutated form in familial amyloidotic polyneuropathies and in an unmutated form in systemic senile amyloidosis. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Amyloidosis

Clinicopathologic Category

Major Fibril Protein

Chemically Related Precursor Protein

Systemic (Generalized) Amyloidosis:

Immunoglobulin light chain amyloidosis (primary amyloidosis)

Seen in Multiple myeloma and other monoclonal plasma cell proliferation

AL

Immunoglobulin light chains, chiefly λ type

Reactive systemic amyloidosis (secondary amyloidosis)

Seen in chronic inflammatory conditions

AA

SAA

Hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis

Seen in chronic renal failure

Aβ2m

β2-microglobulin

Hereditary Amyloidosis:

Familial Mediterranean fever

AA

SAA

Familial amyloidotic neuropathies

ATTR

Mutated transthyretin

Systemic senile amyloidosis

ATTR

Normal transthyretin

Localized Amyloidosis:

Senile cerebral amyloidosis

Seen in Alzheimer's disease

Aβ

APP

Endocrine disorders like Type 2 diabetes

    

Medullary carcinoma thyroid

A Cal

Calcitonin

Islets of Langerhans

AIAPP

Islet amyloid peptide

Isolated atrial amyloidosis

AANF

Atrial natriuretic factor

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought with enlargement of the right testis. USG shows a 3cm solid mass within the body of the testis. Serum AFP is 230 ng/ml. Orchidectomy specimen revealed a nonencapsulated tumour having a homogeneous, yellow-white, mucinous appearance. The microscopy image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is the yolk sac tumor of the testis (Endodermal sinus tumour). 

The given microscopic image shows a lacelike reticular network of cuboidal tumour cells and Schiller duval bodies.

Yolk sac tumor is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age. In this age group, it has a very good prognosis.

 

Eosinophilic, hyaline-like globules may be present within and outside the cytoplasm in which α-fetoprotein (AFP) and α1-antitrypsin can be demonstrated by immunocytochemical staining.

Histology of yolk sac tumour of the testis showing schiller duval bodies (arrow).

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given histopathology slide.
questions.solution:
The slide shows section of the duodenum and marked structures glands located on the duodenum called Brunner's glands

Brunner's glands (or duodenal glands) are compound tubular submucosal glands present in the upper duodenum (above the sphincter of Oddi).

The alveoli of duodenal glands are lined mostly by mucous secreting columnar cells. Their ducts pass through the muscularis mucosae and empty into the intestinal crypts (of Lieberkuhn). 

The duodenum can be easily differentiated from the jejunum or ileum by the presence of these submucosal glands. The jejunum and ileum do not have glands in their submucosa.

questions.text: The histopathological section of the cardiac tissue of an 82-year-old man shows some pigmentation, as seen below. Intracellular accumulation of which of the following is likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Intracellular accumulation of lipofuscin (brown lipid) is seen in this patient. 

Lipofuscin or lipochrome is also known as the wear-and-tear pigment. It is an insoluble, brownish-yellow, granular intracellular material, which accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain. It is seen in normal ageing patients. Accumulation of the brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.  

It is derived from lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids indicating free radical injury. Not injurious to the cell or its functions. It is seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes. The image of lipofuscin is given below.

Option B: Anthracosis leads to accumulations of carbon/coal dust pigment which is seen as black accumulations in the tissues of the lungs and not the heart. The following image shows anthracosis with deposition of black carbon particles, within the cytoplasm of macrophages.

Option C: Melanin is brown-black in color which occurs as a result of oxidation of tyrosine in melanocytes, as shown in the following histopathology of a lymph node. 

Option D: Hemosiderin is a haemoglobin-derived, golden-yellow to brown, granular or crystalline pigment. It is one of the major storage forms of iron and can be seen in iron-overload states like hemochromatosis. The following image shows extensive intra-alveolar hemosiderin deposition following pulmonary haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Three renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, principally hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Renal histopathology in:

  • Amyloidosis: Glomerular deposits appearing as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid
  • Lupus nephritis: Immune complex deposits in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall; lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient presents with anemia. His father and paternal aunt had a similar illness that was treated successfully by splenectomy. His peripheral blood smear is similar to that shown in the illustration below. Which of the following additional abnormalities is expected?
questions.solution:
The above image showing spherocytes present on the peripheral blood smear and, along with the history, strongly suggest a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis (HS). The presence of Howell-Jolly bodies is an additional abnormality which can be expected here.

It is an autosomal dominant inheritance disorder. It is due to defective ankyrin, band 3, spectrin, or band 4.2 proteins causing a defect in the red cell membrane. This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes get trapped in the splenic cords and are phagocytosed by macrophages.

  • Most common mode of inheritance of HS: Autosomal dominant
  • Most common gene mutation in autosomal dominant HS: Ankyrin > Band 3

Clinical presentation:

The patients usually present with anemia, gall stones, splenomegaly, and jaundice but the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. They might also have a family history.

Aplastic crisis might occur where red cell production comes to a halt due to parvovirus infection. This lasts for 1 to 2 weeks which is usually the time required for the immune system to clear the virus. Blood transfusions may be needed during this period.

Morphology :

  • The most common finding is spherocytosis, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor but this is not specific to HS. 
  • Features seen in HS are :
    • Reticulocytosis- increased reticulocyte count
    • Howell-Jolly bodies- dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs.
    • Marrow erythroid hyperplasia
    • Hemosiderosis
  • Splenomegaly as a result of congested Billroth cords and increased phagocytes.

Diagnosis:

Based on family history, peripheral smear findings, and laboratory investigations an adequate diagnosis is made. Increased osmotic fragility is seen in majority of the cases. They also show an increased MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) due to cellular dehydration.

Note- Heinz bodies: Undeterred oxidation of hemoglobin in the RBCs leads to the formation of denatured precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These bodies damage the RBC membrane. When these RBCs pass through the splenic cords, macrophages pluck out these precipitates, giving them the characteristic appearance of bite cells. They are seen in cases of chemical poisoning, drug toxicity, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, or the presence of unstable hemoglobin (e.g. hemoglobin Köln)

Below image shows Heinz bodies and bite cells.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presented with skin-coloured umbilicated nodules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
The given microscopic image shows large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans.

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, and pink to skin-coloured umbilicated papules. A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

Tzanck smear: intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies.

Microscopic examination: Cuplike verrucous epidermal hyperplasia and Molluscum bodies: large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum.

Molluscum bodies contain numerous virions.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless swelling of the neck. The histology of the tissue shows Hurthle cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The slide shows the histopathology of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with:

  • Follicular destruction
  • Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue
  • Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration
  • A well-developed germinal centre may be seen
  • Hurthle/ Askanazy cells that have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm lining the follicles

 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is also known as struma lymphomatosa or lymphocytic thyroiditis. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure.

Clinical features:

  • Most prevalent between 45 - 65 years of age
  • More common in females
  • Painless enlargement of the thyroid
  • Hashitoxicosis: When the auto-antibodies attack and damage the follicles, there is a sudden release of thyroid hormones from these follicles. This leads to a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis.
  • Hypothyroidism: Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism.

Diagnosis:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid receptors
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

These patients are managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

In patients with long-standing goiter, there is a risk of compressive features and development of thyroid lymphoma. Such cases can be treated with total thyroidectomy. It may also predispose to papillary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: You are a pathology resident who is looking at a slide, showing small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes as shown below. The history you received from the pediatric surgery resident was that the specimen was resected from a 5-year-old child with ataxia. The tumor was present in the midline vermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and slide are suggestive of Medulloblastoma. 

Medulloblastoma is an embryonal CNS tumor, occurring predominantly in the cerebellar vermis that causes ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. It may cause obstructive hydrocephalus and often metastasizes extraneurally.

Histopathology shows a tumor composed of small, round, blue cells and is characterized by Homer–Wright rosettes and an immunopositivity for synaptophysin. 

Standard treatment for medulloblastomas is surgical resection, with adjuvant craniospinal radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy.
Prognosis is strongly influenced by surgical resection, the presence of CSF metastases at the time of diagnosis, and the expression of the c-erbB-2 (HER2/neu) oncogene.

Note: Small, round, blue-cell tumors are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic appearance under the microscope. It consists of sheets of small round cells that stain blue on routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. Examples are:

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

A new study shows that children with medulloblastoma who were treated with radiotherapy had better intellectual outcomes when the radiation was delivered as proton beam therapy compared to traditional photon radiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Histopathological examination of an ovarian mass sent to the pathology department revealed the following. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is more common in women with low parity
The pathogenesis is related to family history and heritable mutations
High-grade tumors are associated with TP53 mutations

questions.solution:
The given image denotes Psammoma bodies which are a histopathological finding seen in ovarian papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma. These tumors are most commonly bilateral.

The majority of serous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline. But the serous carcinomas of the ovary include the most common malignant tumors of the ovary. 

Nulliparity, family history, and heritable mutations play a role in the development of these tumors. Mutations in the oncogenes KRAS, BRAF, or ERBB2 result in low-grade tumors, and mutation in TP53 is associated with high-grade tumors. 

There is a higher frequency of carcinoma in women with low parity. Women on oral contraceptive pills or those who have undergone tubal ligation are at a lower risk. The marker for ovarian tumors is CA-125.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented to the OPD with failure to thrive and a developmental defect of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches and was referred for further evaluation. The Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization ( FISH) findings have been shown in the following image. This syndrome is known as____
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 seen on Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) are suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome.

A child with a developmental defect of thymus and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 points towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome.

In this syndrome, the fourth branchial arch and the derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches (which contribute to the formation of the thymus, parathyroids, and heart) develop abnormally. This syndrome is therefore associated with multiple deficits (memorable through the mnemonic CATCH - 22)

Mnemonic CATCH-22:

  • Cardiac abnormality
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia
  • Cleft palate
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Deletion 22q11.2  

Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T-cell immunity can manifest as:

  • T cells are absent in the lymph nodes, spleen, and peripheral blood, and infants with this defect are extremely vulnerable to viral, fungal, and protozoal infections.
  • Patients also are susceptible to infection with intracellular bacteria, because of defective T cell-mediated immunity.
  • B cells and serum immunoglobulins are generally unaffected.

 Other options:

Option A: Williams syndrome occurs due to deletion at chromosome 7. Classical facial features include:

  • Periorbital fullness of subcutaneous tissues,
  • Hypertelorism,
  • A stellate pattern of the iris,
  • Long philtrum,
  • Thick vermillion border of the lips,
  • Wide mouth,
  • Small jaw (elfin facies).

Option B: Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome or Pitt–Rogers–Danks syndrome (PRDS) or Pitt syndrome occurs due to partial deletion or monosomy of chromosome 4. The main features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome are typical “Greek helmet” facies secondary to ocular hypertelorism, prominent glabella, and frontal bossing, and microcephaly.

Option D: Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by the partial deletion of the short arm of Chromosome no. 5. Affected children have a cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with bilateral proptosis. The biopsy from the region shows this pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma.

The biopsy specimen in schwannoma shows hypocellular (Antoni B) and hypercellular areas (Antoni A). Antoni A area has the nuclei of tumor cells aligned in palisading rows. The nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.

The histological section of a schwannoma showing Antoni A, Antoni B and Verocay bodies is given below:

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of having a dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from ________
questions.solution:
The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. Liver microscopy shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's prussian blue stain.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

The characteristic triad of hemochromatosis includes:

  1. Micronodular cirrhosis
  2. Diabetes mellitus in 75% to 80% of patients
  3. Abnormal skin pigmentation in 75% to 80% of patients

Note: The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.

questions.text: A 45 year old male with recurrent bloody diarrhea came to the hospital. Colonoscopy showed geographical ulcers. Histopathology is given below. Your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Crohn's disease.

In the given history, recurrent bloody diarrhea indicates periods of active disease interrupted by asymptomatic periods. The presence of geographical ulcers indicate the presence of multiple, clearly delineated areas of disease in-between areas of normal mucosa, or skip lesions.

The histopathological image shows transmural inflammation where inflammatory cells (neutrophils) extend from mucosa through submucosa, and to the muscularis thereby, infiltrating and damaging crypt epithelium. The normally straight and parallel crypts appear distorted.
All the above features indicate Crohn’s disease to be the diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Difference between Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn's Disease

ULCERATIVE COLITIS CROHN'S DISEASE
Proctocolitis/Backwash ileitis Affects any part of the GIT, most commonly the iliocecal region
Mucosal disease Affects the full thickness of the bowel wall (transmural)
Confluent disease in colon and rectum Skip lesions are characteristic
Strictures and fistulas are not common They are more commonly associated with strictures and fistulas.
Granulomas are not common Granulomas are the hallmark of Crohn's disease
Not associated with perianal disease Associated with perianal disease

It does not usually affect the terminal ileum.

 When symptoms affect the terminal ileum, symptoms may mimic appendicitis.
Resection of the colon and rectum is curative. Recurrence is common after resection.

questions.text: An elderly man with a long-standing history of memory loss and behavioral changes passed away. On autopsy, brain atrophy was noted. A histopathology section of his brain showed the following finding. This protein is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease and the above image shows neurofibrillary tangles inside the neuron. These are formed from helical filaments of abnormal tau proteins.

In Alzheimer’s disease, neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques are found in the brain, especially in the hippocampus. Neurofibrillary tangles are deposited inside the neurons, whereas amyloid plaques are deposited around the neurons.

Other options:

Option A: Amyloid plaques are made of beta-amyloid precursor protein (APP). They are deposited around the neurons. Amyloid plaque is shown in the image below:

Option B: Prions deposit in the neurons and cause apoptosis. The degeneration of these neurons leads to spongiform encephalopathy. The protein gets deposited as plaques.

The image given below shows the spongiform appearance of the brain seen in prion disease.

Option D: Alzheimer's disease may also have Lewy body. Lewy bodies are formed due to the clumping of abnormal alpha-synuclein protein in the neurons. They predominantly cause Lewy body dementia but can also be found in Parkinson’s and Alzhiemer's disease.

The image given below shows Lewy body.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria.  Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in adults. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. 

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is associated with Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: What type of cell is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
In the picture given above, Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells are seen, which is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

Reed–Sternberg cells :

  • RS cells are large and either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (thus resembling an "owl's eye" appearance) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli.
  • The RS cell is clonal in origin and arises from the germinal center B cells but typically has lost most B-cell gene expression and function.
  • Reed Sternberg cells are not diagnostic for any condition since they are seen in many conditions such as:
    • Hodgkin’s lymphoma
    • Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (commonly in immunoblastic type)
    • Infectious mononucleosis
    • Sarcomas


Option A: Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as “Faggot cells” and are marked in the image below by the red arrow (faggot in French means bundle of sticks). 


Option C: Mott cells are plasma cells with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies. They are characteristically seen in multiple myeloma.


Option D: Sézary-Lutzner cells are cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane). These are neoplastic T cells that are seen in mycosis fungoides and Sezary syndrome.

Related Pearl: Variants of Reed Sternberg Cells

Variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the corresponding subtype of Hodgkin's Lymphoma

  • Lacunar Variant: Nodular Sclerosis
  • Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 
  • Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 
  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: The histological finding shown in the image below is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows fried egg appearance of cells is seen in Oligodendroglioma.

  • These are infiltrating gliomas comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes.
  • Common in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a pre­dilection for white matter.
  • The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect around neurons (perineuronal satellitosis).
  • Fried eggs in pathology:
    • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
    • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
    • Seminoma/Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
    • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

questions.text: A female patient presented with a lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An asymmetrical lesion, with an irregular border, with black/brown pigmentation points towards a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. 

Types of melanoma:

  • Lentigo maligna
  • Superficial spreading
  • Acral lentiginous
  • Nodular

Histopathology of melanoma:

  • Individual melanoma cells are larger than normal melanocytes
  • They have large nuclei with irregular contours, chromatin is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane with prominent red eosinophilic nucleoli
  • All tumors have a vertical and radial phase of growth. The appearance of melanocytes is similar in both phases. The vertical growth has is often heralded by the appearance of a nodule.
  • The possibility of metastasis correlates with the depth of invasion which is called the Breslow thickness.
Type Clinical features Spread
Basal cell carcinoma

Nodule

Central ulceration with a pearly surface,

telangiectasia

Squamous cell carcinoma

Ulcer with thickened margins, keratosis

Papillomatous

Local,

lymph nodes
Malignant melanoma

>6 mm pigmented, 

vascularization

inflammation

vascular

lymph nodes

questions.text: A farmer presents with a warty cutaneous growth on his foot. Histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutter and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Other options:

Mycetoma:

  • It is caused by various types of Fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form which breaks down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of Foot.

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics.

Phaeohyphomycosis : it is a chronic fungal infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The lesions maybe plaques which are verrucous, hypertkeratotis or ulcerated. The fungi implicated are usually of the class Phialophora or Cladophora or other demetacious fungi.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with an ovarian tumor. Histopathological examination of tumor specimen reveals sheets of mucin-producing signet ring cells as seen below.  Identify the true statement regarding this ovarian tumor.

choices.text: Normal shape of ovary is retained
Ovary is attached to nearby viscera and becomes immobile

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing signet ring cells is suggestive of Krukenberg tumor and in this ovarian tumor, the normal shape of the ovary is retained.

Krukenberg tumor: These are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from a primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral (Option D)
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis (Option C)
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule (Option A)
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, Numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.

questions.text: This characteristic appearance of T-lymphocytes is seen in ______
questions.solution:
The image shows a characteristic cerebriform appearance of T-lymphocytes as seen in Mycosis fungoides.

  • Histopathology findings
    • Moderate lymphocytic infiltrate in papillary dermis
    • Epidermotropism (presence of lymphocytes in the epidermal cells)
    • Pautriers’s microabscesses consisting of clusters of atypical lymphocytes
    • Atypical lymphocytes have a cerebriform appearance with irregular nuclear outline and halo around cells.

Image: Typical epidermotropism (presence of lymphocytes in the epidermal cells) seen in Mycosis fungoides.

Image: Plaques seen in Mycosis fungoides

questions.text: A patient working in a factory presented with lung fibrosis and thickening of pleura. Biopsy was done. Diagnosis from the histopathology picture is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows typical asbestos bodies giving the diagnosis of asbestosis.

The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility.

  • Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis, which is differentiated from other causes of diffuse interstitial fibrosis by the presence of multiple asbestos bodies.
  • Asbestos bodies are golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods with a translucent center. They consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material and arise when macrophages phagocytose asbestos fibers.
  • Other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes and are called ferruginous bodies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presented to the clinic with reddening and itching over the left breast as shown in the figure. Mammogram showed the presence of microcalcifications in the left breast. Histopathology shows the presence of large pale vacuolated cells with round nuclei in the epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and histology are diagnostic of Paget's disease of the breast. 

Paget’s disease is a superficial manifestation of underlying malignancy.

Clinically it presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple which may progress to ulceration. In the majority of patients, there is also an underlying breast lump. This lump is usually DCIS. Less commonly it can also be invasive ductal carcinoma.

A nipple biopsy specimen will show a population of cells that are identical to the underlying malignant cells. The presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with round or oval nuclei are pathognomonic for this condition.

Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or mastectomy.

Note: 

Paget's disease can be often confused with superficial spreading melanoma. Paget's disease shows positive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreading melanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with obesity, metabolic syndrome, and renal failure presents with excruciating joint pain associated with localized hyperemia and warmth involving ankles, heels, and knees.  Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and crystals seen under polarised light are as  shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is gout. Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and crystals which are long, slender, needle-shaped, and negatively birefringent

Gout is marked by transient attacks of acute arthritis initiated by crystallization of monosodium urate within and around joints.

Gout can be classified into primary and secondary forms.

The inflammation in gout is triggered by precipitation of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals into the joints, which results in the production of cytokines that recruit leukocytes.

Macrophages phagocytose the MSU and the inflammasome activates caspase-1, which is involved in the production of some biologically active cytokines.

IL-1 is pro-inflammatory and promotes accumulation of neutrophils and macrophages in the joint

The distinctive morphologic changes in gout are (1) acute arthritis,(2) chronic tophaceous arthritis, (3) tophi in various sites, and (4) gouty nephropathy

Tophi are the pathognomonic hallmark of gout- large aggregations of urate crystals surrounded by an intense inflammatory reaction of foreign body giant cells which may appear in the articular cartilage, ligaments, tendons, and bursae, earlobes, fingertips, or kidneys.

Gouty nephropathy refers to the renal complications caused by MSU crystals or tophi in the renal medullary interstitium or tubules. Complications include uric acid nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis.

Gout has been known since antiquity. Historically, it was referred to as "the disease of kings/rich man's disease" because of the lavish diet and alcohol consumption of the wealthy.

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding

Gout

Pseudogout

Crystal composition

Uric acid

Calcium pyrophosphate

Shape

Needle like

Rhomboid

Birefringence pattern

Negative

Weak positive

Most commonly affected joint

1st MTP

Knee

X-ray findings

Periarticular erosions with overhanging margins

Chondrocalcinosis

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient came with complaints of hematuria to the clinic. On examination, he was normotensive and had pedal edema. Investigations revealed the patient had no glycosuria and had a creatinine of 9. His renal biopsy is shown below. Which of the following investigations should be done to identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical history and microscopy showing crescents, RPGN (type -1) is suspected. To confirm anti-GBM (Glomerular basement membrane) antibody testing should be done.

Type 1 RPGN includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. In this condition, antibodies are produced against the non-collagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM.

Microscopy findings of Goodpasture's disease are:

  • Immunofluorescence - linear deposits of Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron microscopy - wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal disruptions without any immune complex deposition.

A variant of Goodpasture's disease with pulmonary involvement is known as Goodpasture's syndrome.

Option A: ANA(Antinuclear Antibody) testing is done if SLE is suspected. Electron microscopy will show immune complex deposits.

Option C: HIV RNA in case of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Electron microscopy will show diffuse podocyte injury with complete foot process effacement. 

Option D: Serum electrophoresis is done for multiple myeloma.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Disease

Electron microscopy

Postinfectious glomerulo-nephritis

Diffuse endocapillary proliferation; leukocytic infiltration

Granular IgG and C3 in glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, 

Granular IgA in some cases

Nephrotic syndrome:

Membranous  nephropathy

No deposits.

Nephrito-nephrotic syndrome:   

Membrano-proliferative glomerulo-nephritis

(MPGN) type I

Mesangial proliferative or membrano-proliferative patterns of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

IgG ++ C3; C1q ++ C4

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

 

Image – Linear, smooth diffuse pattern of staining for IgG in Goodpasture syndrome:

questions.text: The vascular lesion shown below is characteristic of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The given image shows hyaline arteriosclerosis. It is not a characteristic lesion of severe hypertension.  

Hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs in the following conditions:

  • Elderly patients who are normotensive
  • Benign hypertension- due to chronic hemodynamic stresses
  • Diabetes mellitus- due to hyperglycemia-induced endothelial dysfunction. Hyaline arteriosclerosis is a common feature of diabetic microangiopathy.

The characteristic vascular lesion of severe hypertension is hyperplastic arteriosclerosis as seen in the image below.

questions.text: A patient has HbA2 3% and HbF 97%. A peripheral blood smear was taken. Which of the following blood pictures will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of HbA2 3% and HbF 97% indicates that it is a case of thalassemia major. In thalassemia major, hematological findings in image 1 showing poikilocytes and image 3 showing target cells are seen. Image 2 showing Howell jolly bodies are seen in post-splenectomy thalassemia patients and not in this case.

Hematological findings in thalassemia major include the following:

  • Anisopoikilocytosis
  • Target cells (codocytes)
  • Nucleated RBC’s
  • Dacrocytes
  • Basophilic stippling
  • Polychromatophilic cells

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

The table below describes the features of typical thalassemia syndromes:

Alpha thalassemias  Hb Barts HbH disease  Minor Silent carrier

Hemoglobin electro-phoresis Hb Barts (γ globin tetramers); Hb Portland (embryonic hemoglobin); no HbF, HbA, or HbA2 HbH (beta-globin tetramers -up to 30%); HbA2 (up to 4%) Hb Barts (3 to 8%) Normal

"-" denotes deletion of an alpha gene and "α" denotes normal alpha gene and "α* " refers to a mutant alpha chain gene.

β0 refers to no beta-globin production; β+ refers to decreased beta-globin production.

Related Pearl: Features of peripheral blood smear in different anemias

questions.text: A patient died due to encephalitis. A postmortem biopsy of the brain tissue is shown below. This finding is characteristic of infection caused by:
questions.solution:
The finding in the image shows Negri bodies, which is characteristic of the infection caused by the rabies virus.

Negri bodies are pathognomonic of rabies virus infection. These are spherical-shaped cytoplasmic inclusion bodies. They contain eosinophilic matrix, basophilic granules, and viral antigens. 

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped, and contain single-stranded RNA.

Clinical features of rabies can be categorized into three phases: prodromal, encephalitic phase, and coma. Prodromal phase is characterised by malaise, anorexia, headache, and irritability. This is followed by the encephalitic stage characterized by abnormal behavior and seizures. They develop hydrophobia. Attempts to drink liquids cause painful spasms of the pharynx and larynx, producing a choking sensation. Therefore, the patients develop a phobia of even the sight or sound of water. Finally, seizures, coma, and death occur.

Laboratory diagnosis can be done on a postmortem or antemortem basis. Postmortem diagnosis is done by the demonstration of Negri bodies. These bodies are common in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. Antemortem diagnosis is done from corneal scrapings, saliva, or skin biopsy. Demonstration of the virus is done using direct immunofluorescence. 

Other methods used in the diagnosis are intracerebral inoculation in the mice, tissue culture, ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay), and PCR (polymerase chain reaction).
